reasoning: The critique targets a key sub-argument in §3.2: that on unbounded linear views, a fat-tailed distribution of value-per-resource makes mostly-great futures a very narrow target unless resources are used in near-optimal ways. If that inference fails, the paper’s case that “linear views are fussy” is notably weakened, but it wouldn’t by itself collapse the full ‘no easy eutopia’ position because the essay also leans on other routes to fussiness (multiplicative fragility across dimensions; bounded-view arguments about bads; other moral-catastrophe mechanisms). The objection is moderately strong: it correctly notes that fat tails don’t entail extreme sparsity of near-optima, and that design spaces can have broad near-optimal plateaus, so the authors would need an additional argument connecting fat tails to a small measure of >50%-optimal configurations. However, it doesn’t fully rebut the authors’ added considerations (e.g., separability/replicability claims, and the possibility that the distribution is not just fat-tailed but sharply concentrated away from near-optima), so it’s more a gap-pointing challenge than a decisive refutation. The critique is mostly correct and clearly stated, tightly focused, with little to no dead weight.
title: Fat-tailed value distributions can still have broad near-optimal plateaus, not needle targets
